response.answer_text: We will become the Borg  Humans are social beings and we often ask others for advice on life decisions. In my opinion the magnitude of the decisions where we ask for others opinions is constantly shrinking. Many young people start outsourcing decision making into their social network crowds. With live videos and shiny voting buttons or sliders they get immediate feedback of their followers and peers. Now imagine if we get a direct internet connection to our brain. It will probably take some more decades, but I think many of us will see it in their lifetimes. Now you can upload everything you see to the cloud. This is already happening in Instagram/Snap,… but not in real time and not in such an extent. After a while it will really hurt to go offline and people will be scared to be on their own. How can you know that you are going to make the best decision? Its a scary world when you are alone. It will feel so much better to be part of a collective consciousness that more and more people will join it. This will for sure end wars and increase compassion to all other humans since they all become one. Funnily enough this sounds like Mahāyāna branch of Buddhism, bringing all of humanity together to the single entity they are and which created our universe :) Resistance is futile!

Rather strangely, we are now in a position to make some reasonable predictions on this matter, although uncertainties remain. One thing is assured, though - we snoutless apes are fast becoming redundant to the evolutionary process that can be traced at least as far back as the formation of the chemical elements in the first stars. Most folk still seem unable to break free from the traditional science fiction based notions involving individual robots/computers. Either as potential threats, beneficial aids or serious basis for "artificial intelligence". In actuality, the real next cognitive entity quietly self assembles in the background, mostly unrecognized for what it is. And, contrary to our usual conceits, is not stoppable or directly within our control. We are very prone to anthropocentric distortions of objective reality. This is perhaps not surprising, for to instead adopt the evidence based viewpoint now afforded by "big science" and "big history" takes us way outside our perceptive comfort zone. The fact is that the evolution of the Internet (and, of course, major components such as Google) is actually an autonomous process. The difficulty in convincing people of this "inconvenient truth" seems to stem partly from our natural anthropocentric mind-sets and also the traditional illusion that in some way we are in control of, and distinct from, nature. Contemplation of the observed realities tend to be relegated to the emotional "too hard" bin. This evolution is not driven by any individual software company or team of researchers, but rather by the sum of many human requirements, whims and desires to which the current technologies react. Among the more significant motivators are such things as commerce, gaming, social interactions, education and sexual titillation. Virtually all interests are catered for and, in toto provide the impetus for the continued evolution of the Internet. Netty is still in her larval stage, but we "workers" scurry round mindlessly engaged in her nurture. By relinquishing our usual parochial approach to this issue in favor of the overall evolutionary "big picture" provided by many fields of science, the emergence of a new predominant cognitive entity (from the Internet, rather than individual machines) is seen to be not only feasible but inevitable Stephen Hawking, for instance, is reported to have remarked "Whereas the short-term impact of AI depends on who controls it, the long-term impact depends on whether it can be controlled at all," This statement reflects the narrow-minded approach that is so common-place among those who make public comment on this issue. In reality, as much as it may offend our human conceits, the march of technology and its latest spearhead, the Internet is, and always has been, an autonomous process over which we have very little real control. Seemingly unrelated disciplines such as geology, biology and "big history" actually have much to tell us about the machinery of nature (of which technology is necessarily a part) and the kind of outcome that is to be expected from the evolution of the Internet. This much broader "systems analysis" approach, freed from the anthropocentric notions usually promoted by the cult of the "Singularity", provides a more objective vision that is consistent with the pattern of autonomous evolution of technology that is so evident today. Very real evidence indicates the rather imminent implementation of the next, (non-biological) phase of the on-going evolutionary “life” process from what we at present call the Internet. It is effectively evolving by a process of self-assembly. The "Internet of Things" is proceeding apace and pervading all aspects of our lives. We are increasingly, in a sense, “enslaved” by our PCs, mobile phones, their apps and many other trappings of the increasingly cloudy net. We are already largely dependent upon it for our commerce and industry and there is no turning back. What we perceive as a tool is well on its way to becoming an agent. There are at present an estimated 2 Billion Internet users. There are an estimated 10 to 80 Billion neurons in the human brain. On this basis for approximation the Internet is even now only one order of magnitude below the human brain and its growth is exponential. That is a simplification, of course. For example: Not all users have their own computer. So perhaps we could reduce that, say, tenfold. The number of switching units, transistors, if you wish, contained by all the computers connecting to the Internet and which are more analogous to individual neurons is many orders of magnitude greater than 2 Billion. Then again, this is compensated for to some extent by the fact that neurons do not appear to be binary switching devices but instead can adopt multiple states. Without even crunching the numbers, however, we see that we must take seriously the possibility that even the present Internet may well be comparable to a human brain in processing power. And, of course, the degree of interconnection and cross-linking of networks within networks is also growing rapidly. The emergence of a new and predominant cognitive entity that is a logical consequence of the evolutionary continuum that can be traced back at least as far as the formation of the chemical elements in stars. This is the main theme of my latest book "The Intricacy Generator: Pushing Chemistry and Geometry Uphill" which is now available as a 336 page illustrated paperback from Amazon, etc. There is absolutely no reason to assume "life" has any "purpose". On the other hand the evolving network of our universe very observably has directionality. And it may well be that the tiny cog in nature's machinery to which species comparable to ours correspond may typically self-destruct once the next, non-biological, phase of the evolutionary process is well established. Since its precursor, the Internet (and peripherals) is growing exponentially, that day might not be far off for us. On the other hand, we could possibly earn a reprieve by becoming amicable symbionts with the new cognitive entity. The benefits from such an arrangement could be great. But we first have to become aware of the process and take steps to curb our inherent belligerence. Straighten up and fly right!

Well, just "a future" is a pretty broad definition. I think it's likely that we still exist next week, although I'm not certain. The future of every species, once it fully populates its habitat, is decline and extinction. There are a few very specific problems limiting further development of H. sapiens: Negative correlation of birth rate and intelligence. This means intelligence is declining over time. Probably without the selection pressure from the hunter gatherer lifestyle, there is not enough need for individual problem solving. There is a lot of dependence on large groups in which only one person needs to be able to solve a problem. There was a brief increase in developed countries due to improved nutrition, and this is now playing out in developing nations, but it soon peaks. Browse on Quora for a couple of years if you don’t believe intelligence is declining. I’ve seen question quality decline over that time.Mostly negative correlation of birth rate and non-reproductive success measures such as wealth. There is an exception for billionaires, but there are not enough of those to affect the species statistically. This again I attribute to the effect of groups, and I suspect it has been going on since the invention of agriculture, but accelerating since the colonial era with the global consolidation of political entities. When a hero became a chief and had several wives and many children, evolution was rapid. Now anyone who collects several wives is thrown in jail. There is no reproductive advantage to success, so the human race is becoming accomplishment impoverished. This is camouflaged by every larger countries and even globalism, as those that are accomplished are known around the world.Centralization of decision making limits variety of approaches to life. The world is now like a huge committee. Everyone has to approve everything, so absolutely nothing gets done. Anyone can say no. Even people without political power can start a social media campaign and have whatever they object to declared to be tragically politically incorrect or even a crime. The internet has had a devastating effect on human evolution.Limits to cooperation in extremely large groups. There are several kinds of cooperation. The cooperative or altruistic personality trait is thought by biologists to be extremely limited, only to close family kin. Reciprocal cooperation can arise in unrelated people in a network in which they are likely to have multiple transactions with the same person or group. Too large a group makes repeating transactions less likely. While internet business tries to overcome this with customer reviews, that works only as long as there are only a few products with a decent product life, and no one figures out how to fake reviews.Negative correlation of cooperation and intelligence. If people are smart, or if you explain game theory to them, they cooperate less, because they realize cooperation exposes them to being taken advantage of.I propose starting a new species deliberately to replace humans. It’s the only way we will have some control over our replacements. Otherwise something like AI will arise and just remove us, or maybe a highly regulated and standardized gene editing regime will centralize reproduction, effectively making social insects out of us. The replacements would need to be CRISPR modified with codes determined from GWAS in at least the following areas: Increased intelligenceIncreased reproductive drive to compensate the negative birth rate / intelligence correlation.Selective reproductive drive to avoid diluting intelligence by breeding back with ordinary humans (this is what makes it a separate species, not a race or other group within H. sapiens).Behavioral modifications (to be determined by research) that give an advantage to cooperation. Just modifying behavior to be more cooperative, without an advantage, would make the new species vulnerable to humans and it would extinguish quickly. Making it more intelligent without such modifications would give up all cooperation advantage and it could not compete with less smart but superstitiously cooperative H. sapiens. The behavioral solution has not yet been found. This is the main holdup, not the genetic techniques.Long life is not in there because as far as I know those alleles have not been identified. They don’t exist in the human species. Intelligence does. Some degree of cooperative behavior does. Whether they can occur together is a question. One idea is that this new group will have the wherewithal to figure out most of the rest of what they need.

The question is, “What is next in the development of mankind?” A unified society on this planet. Over the course of history, humans have developed larger and larger groupings. We could consider marriage to be the first such grouping, followed by family, tribe, city, and nation. We stand today at the end of the period during which nations were adequate to human needs. Many of the world’s ills today, such as war, hunger, and terrorism, are products of unresolved international conflict. Eventually, we will need to develop a way to resolve these conflicts. At this point we will, by definition, live in a unified world. There are many dystopian scenarios about a unified world, and some aspects of those are evident even today, such as the international power of giant corporations, which far exceed the size and power of many nations. However, these dystopian aspects will be overcome, and just as there are many nations today that are composed of separate states or provinces, so in the future the world will have a single super-state that is composed of all the separate nations. Here are some requirements for the qualities of that super-state. Far from aiming at the subversion of the existing foundations of society, it seeks to broaden its basis, to remold its institutions in a manner consonant with the needs of an ever-changing world. It can conflict with no legitimate allegiances, nor can it undermine essential loyalties. Its purpose is neither to stifle the flame of a sane and intelligent patriotism in men’s hearts, nor to abolish the system of national autonomy so essential if the evils of excessive centralization are to be avoided. It does not ignore, nor does it attempt to suppress, the diversity of ethnical origins, of climate, of history, of language and tradition, of thought and habit, that differentiate the peoples and nations of the world. It calls for a wider loyalty, for a larger aspiration than any that has animated the human race. It insists upon the subordination of national impulses and interests to the imperative claims of a unified world. It repudiates excessive centralization on one hand, and disclaims all attempts at uniformity on the other. —The World Order of Bahá’u’lláh. Here is a description of what that super-state will look like. Some form of a world super-state must needs be evolved, in whose favor all the nations of the world will have willingly ceded every claim to make war, certain rights to impose taxation and all rights to maintain armaments, except for purposes of maintaining internal order within their respective dominions. Such a state will have to include within its orbit an international executive adequate to enforce supreme and unchallengeable authority on every recalcitrant member of the commonwealth; a world parliament whose members shall be elected by the people in their respective countries and whose election shall be confirmed by their respective governments; and a supreme tribunal whose judgment will have a binding effect even in such cases where the parties concerned did not voluntarily agree to submit their case to its consideration. A world community in which all economic barriers will have been permanently demolished and the interdependence of Capital and Labor definitely recognized; in which the clamor of religious fanaticism and strife will have been forever stilled; in which the flame of racial animosity will have been finally extinguished; in which a single code of international law—the product of the considered judgment of the world’s federated representatives—shall have as its sanction the instant and coercive intervention of the combined forces of the federated units; and finally a world community in which the fury of a capricious and militant nationalism will have been transmuted into an abiding consciousness of world citizenship—such indeed, appears, in its broadest outline, the Order anticipated by Bahá’u’lláh, an Order that shall come to be regarded as the fairest fruit of a slowly maturing age. —ibid. It should be noted that in order for this super-state to be formed, every nation will have voluntarily joined it. Thus, its authority will be the authority of the entire human race.

A lot like the past: chaotic, unpredictable, and far too random to make a good story. Specifically, I suspect (for several reasons) that the next few centuries will be a bit like the Dark Age in the European Early Middle Ages. Not necessarily dangerous or primitive, but social structures will become transient and small-scale. This has actually been happening for some time. When the United Nations was formed, just after World War II, there were 40 nations in the world. Now, there are over 200. There have been exactly two occasions in that period when the number decreased: the re-unification of Germany, and Indonesia’s annexation of East Timor, which lasted for 23 years before a UN-sponsored referendum restored the former Portuguese colony to independence. As for transience, I’m a Baby Boomer. When I grew up, most of the time the way you related to government or corporate bodies was very similar to how your parents and grandparents had. Nowadays, rules and protocols change by the year, if not the month. Then, too, there are environmental problems. Most people nowadays have heard about Global Warming, but those of us who pay attention to such things are also worried about loss of biodiversity, degradation of agricultural lands, habitat loss, chemical pollution, unsupervised genetic modification, and a host of other issues. Greenies are often accused of being alarmist Cassandras. I have my own issues with their attitudes: I think they’re too optimistic. I suspect this century will see so much environmental devastation and human misery that people will give up, stop caring, and (in the long run) make things even worse. The Sixth Extinction (Holocene extinction - Wikipedia) is just getting underway, but in the next few centuries I expect that most species now alive will become extinct. Symbiosis: humanity finds a new symbiosis with the planet and manages to live in a sustainable harmony through advances in technology combined with a slowing or controlling of consumption and population growth 2. Decline of humans to manageable level before Earth is destroyed: some catastrophic event or natural result of overpopulation means we drop down to a more sustainable level of humans. 3. Finding a new host: humans escape the planet and go on to colonise (or parasitically destroy) other worlds, spreading across the galaxy 4. Destruction of host and humanity: we carry on and end up destroying the planet and ourselves in the process. Personally I suspect the reality will sit somewhere between these two extremes - the extreme optimism of singularity and pessimism of parasitic collapse.
